landing.title: Nishchint Setu
landing.subtitle: Your bridge to safety. Real-time conversation monitoring to protect you and your loved ones from phone scams, with privacy at its core.

features.title: A Guardian Angel for Your Digital Life

risk.title: Real-Time Risk Analysis
risk.description: Analyzes conversations live on your device to detect suspicious keywords and patterns associated with common scams.

privacy.title: 100% Private
privacy.description: No audio or transcript data is ever sent to the cloud. All analysis happens locally, ensuring your conversations remain private.

alerts.title: Guardian Alerts
alerts.description: If a potential threat is identified, your chosen emergency contact is alerted with the conversation context to help you.

assistance.title: Guided Assistance
assistance.description: Detects if you're stuck and offers simple, clear options to get you back on track, ensuring a stress-free experience.

step1.title: Create & Pair
step1.description: Set up your profile and share your unique ID with a trusted family member or friend.

step2.title: Live Monitoring
step2.description: Our AI analyzes calls and messages for scam risks, privately on your device.

step3.title: Instant Alerts
step3.description: If a high-risk situation is detected, your guardian is notified instantly to help.

ecResources.title: Scam Prevention Resources
ecResources.cardDescription: Knowledge is the best defense. Learn to recognize these common tactics.

techSupport.title: Tech Support Scams
techSupport.description: Scammers pretend to be from a well-known tech company and claim there's a problem with your computer. They'll ask for remote access or payment to 'fix' a non-existent issue. Never give remote access to your computer to someone who calls you out of the blue.

impersonation.title: Impersonation Scams (e.g., Police, Bank)
impersonation.description: A scammer calls pretending to be from the police, your bank, or another authority figure. They create a sense of urgency, claiming you owe money or your account is compromised, and pressure you into sending money or sharing sensitive information. Legitimate organizations will never demand immediate payment over the phone with gift cards or wire transfers.

lottery.title: Lottery or Prize Scams
lottery.description: You receive a call or message saying you've won a large prize, but you must first pay a fee for taxes or processing. If you have to pay money to get a prize, it's a scam. You should never have to pay to receive a legitimate winning.

otp.title: OTP/Verification Code Scams
otp.description: Someone calls or texts asking you to share a One-Time Password (OTP) or verification code that was just sent to your phone. They might claim it's to verify your identity or stop a fraudulent transaction. This code is for you and you alone. Sharing it gives them access to your account.

relationship.title: Relationship or 'Grandparent' Scams
relationship.description: A scammer builds an online relationship or pretends to be a grandchild in trouble. They'll invent an emergency (like needing bail money or medical fees) and ask you to send money immediately and secretly. Always verify such stories by contacting the person or other family members through known, trusted phone numbers.

safetyTips: Never share your OTP (One-Time Password) with anyone, not even bank employees.
If someone pressures you to act immediately, it's a red flag. A legitimate organization will give you time to think.
Be skeptical of unsolicited calls or messages asking for personal or financial information.
Government agencies like the IRS or Social Security Administration will not call you to demand immediate payment.
Never click on suspicious links sent via text or email, especially those related to refunds or account verification.
If a deal seems too good to be true, it probably is. Always verify offers with the official company.
Do not install any apps or software on your phone or computer at the request of an unknown caller.
